monogr.title: A preparatiue to contentation : conteining a display of the wonderfull distractions of men in opinions and straunge conceits: and of the seuerall discontentations which are incident to euerie particular vocation and condition of men in this life, with the causes and inconueniences of the same: also how they may be either salued or qualified, pacified or eased. Consected applicatorie, especially to this people and time, as an argument most necessary and profitable to be vrged. By Iohn Carpenter
monogr.author: Carpenter, John

div.head: To the true Christian and indifferent Readers, Peace, Contentation, and Saluation in Christ Iesu, the Author and worker of the same.
div.p:
THere is no man liuing vnder the Sun, which feeleth not the painfull effect of Adams sinne, in the bitter sence of wofull miseries. But the godly and best disposed persons, in whatsoeuer time, place, or calling they liue, are constrained with Simon of Cirene to beare the Crosse after their Maister Christ. For why, there be not only ministred vnto them many mightie causes of Discontentation, through those greeuous oppressiōs vrged on them by the vngodly, whom the Lord maketh his roddes to correct and punish his owne when they offende him: wherby the very heart of Mary is pearced with the sword, as Simeon prophesied: but also the holie spirit in them is moued, through the horrible sinnes and greeuous offences of the ingratefull against God, to driue the mestiue mill of lamentation, with flouds of weeping teares. All rhe which (neuerthelesse) the Lord of mercie, and God of consolation, mittigateth and moderateth in them that feare and loue him, both by the inward comforts of his spirit, and by the externall ministerie of his word. But as for the vngodly (which are meere straungers from the wombe, and naturally deuoyd of peace, like the raging waues of the sea that cast out their own filth) the Lord suffreth Satan to rule them at his pleasure: he giueth them ouer, to be destroyed in their owne lusts, as such of whom he hath no regard, and suffereth them to speake lyes, to prophane his holy religion, and to sway in their abhominable sinnes, vntil
their wickednesse be full, when he is willing to require them with his iust iudgements in displeasure. In the meane time, waxing proud, and climbing on high through hautie presumptiō of the Lords long suffring (which should rather drawe sinners to repentance) they take no meane pleasure and glory to oppresse and offend the Lords little ones, and daily deuise and endeuour to disturbe & trouble the profitable tranquilitie and peace of the Christian Common-weale: wheras placing the Lord Iesus on the high Pinacle of the Temple, they assaie how they might cast him downe headlong, to the great griefe of the godly thereby offended, the dishonour of Christ, therby contemned: and the prouocation of the God of heauen, thereby displeased and vrged to powre downe his terrible vengeance and vnhappie woe vppon them by whome those offences come. The state & condition not only of other times and nations, but also of this our owne, yeeld vs too many pittifull examples of this Argument. Wherein, we see how the rough raging waues of humane deuises, suggested and prouoked by the high blustring winds of diuellish Ambition, haue not a litle molested and perplexed (I say not those Marriners that embarqued Ionas towardes Tharsus only, but also) Noah and his familie in the Arke: the Apostles of Christ in the ship, and such as are passengers euen in the same vessell with Christ towardes the Hauen of happinesse. Besides that, we may see, how that on the very maine land, litle Dauid hath very much ado to rescue the seely sheepe from the hungrie Lyons teeth. An house is much sooner throwne downe, then reedified: a Citie is not so easily reduced into
vnitie and concorde, as it is diuided. And surely there, where the distracted mindes and wandering opinions of ambitious heads, haue not only contriued and commenced, but also drawne foorth and twisted the odious threede of Discontentation, wee may expect none other thing therof, but vtter subuertions of Townes, Cities, Countries, Churches, Kingdomes, without speedie preuention. Therefore, this is that, which in the account of all wise men is vnhappie, and after the iudgement of all the godly, most vngodly, and the occasion of greater courage and boldnesse to the forraign enemy, then the feeblest resistances of them that be combined in true concord and peace.

But what is that to vs? I would (indeede) that these things did neither touch vs, nor were found rowsting in our houses! but, when the vizard of hautie conceit and proper integritie, is remooued from our bleared eyes, we cannot but plainly perceiue, that the Church (notwithstanding the sincere preaching of the word of God in the same) is intollerably burthened with Sectes opinions, and dangerous Scismes: and that the whole Common-wealth is no lesse vnhappily pestred with discords, dissentions, seditions, and many other huge enormities and euilles of this last age and wane of the worlde, wherein the bande of Christian Charitie is broken, he Truth (though so strong and aboue all) is entertained but as a wandering Pilgrime on the earth, euen with them that fawne on her presence: the right faith is sorely cōtemned by them that haue taken vp weapons vnder pretence to defende her: and the Prince of darknesse groweth stronger and
stronger without resistance, towards the end of his raigne in the world, who hath vehemently enflamed and strongly prouoked the enemies of the Church against the Church: to the which they threaten fire and sword, and daily endeuor destruction. And this to compasse & effect, they haue ioyned hands with mightie Potentates, they haue armed wel waged souldiers, they haue prepared their strong barbed Horses, their swift Chariots, and a thousand warlike engins, to the terror of the weake in spirit, to the affliction of poore Ioseph, and to the dishonor of the name of God: who laugheth them to scorne, and knoweth wel how to confound them in their owne deuises, when it shall please him to expresse his displeasure towards them, and his loue to his children. But what inconueniences may ensue the present mischiefes, who knoweth not, that hath wisedome to discerne thereof? and what good Christian would not endeuour to stop and preuent the same? Therfore (though after many others, yet with and among some others) to meete with those desperate maladies, and to assay to preuent whatsoeuer greater euils may thereof ensue (according to that meane wisedome and abilitie the Lord hath giuen me) I haue confected A Preparatiue to Contentation: and made the same Applicatory to this our time, Nation, and the present occasion. An Argument most necessary to be vrged, and a thing in earnest expectation of all good mindes, within whom the holy spirit of discipline is made sad and sorrowfull, through the considerarion of the manifold disorders and huge inconueniences of noysome Discontentation, and to whose good natures, the true
Contentation, is euery way both profitable and acceptable, in the feare of God, and honour of the Prince, (howsoeuer harrish and vnpleasant it seemeth to the taste of him that is oppressed with the humor of singular conceit) as those potions which are in taste bitter and sowre, may be more wholsom for the distressed patient, then such as are sweet and wallowish. And (indeed) although I could not be so briefe as Phocian was in the Citie of Athenes: nor (if I could) would I be either so copious as Demosthenes with the Graecians, or so eloquent as Cicero with the Romains, to whose learned immitatours I referre both the lapping vp of plaine things in obscuritie, and the handling of publique controuersies in ample discourses: yet haue I wished and indeuoured to be rather modest with Paule, and charitable with Iohn, then impudent with Tartullus, and curious with Peter: hazarding al my credit & ease, in regard of your profit and peace. Moreouer, albeit I know wel, that to many of you, this my present Preparatiue shalbe but like the glimmering light of a Candle set in the bright Sun shining, hauing (indeed) litle need of this meane helpe: yet I perswade, that ye which loue brotherly fellowship, feare God, and honour the Prince, will not disdaine it, but rather, that ye will be the more readie vpon this, and such like occasiōs, to stand vp in the defence of the truth against all erronious opinions, vaine deuises, and synister practises of man, as it best becommeth you with all such as be of the houshold of faith. Neither doubt I, but that also the sooner by the force of this Preparatiue, the rage and rygour of the Discontented wil be asswaged, the domesticall enemy in part, terrified,
the seditious Aduersary of our state quailed, or at the least made ashamed, and the forreine foe the better obserued and resisted: that so, both in the one and the other, the Lord of heauen may be worthely glorified. For these causes haue I the rather published this Preparatiue, the which also I pray and beseech you (Christian Readers) before the Lord Iesus, and his holy Angels, to take in good part, and to construe therof indifferently, to apply it discreetly, and to vse it in all points charitably, for the better quiet of conscience, the peace of the Church, and safetie of the Common-wealth, in the feare of God: vnto whose goodnesse, let vs daily pray for the true Contentation.
